I had an opportunity to work and serve on selection boards.

to get it.

If you're going to get it, you're going to get it.

So, you know, don't want to have a history lesson for everybody out there.
But because of the failure of the Iranian hostage rescue mission in April of 1980 and
that, it's a civilian side of the house, it made the decision that, especially because
of the failure of the Iranian hostage rescue mission, that if we as a nation want to have
an organization that be able to conduct no fail missions, that we need to be serious
about this.
And there has to be one command that's organized, trained and equipped to be able to do that.
That started shaping the community.
But we were still in the Navy, the Army was still in the Army.
And through the Department of Defense Appropriation Act of 1987, Senators None and Cohen tacked
on the end of that appropriations bill, the establishment of the United States Special
Operations Command and bringing in the Navy Seals, Army Special Forces Rangers and
as 160th and Air Force Commandos under the United States Special Operations Command.
So then we had our own line of money for unique.
But be honest with you, at that time, my friend Tom Coulter, who mentioned that, once the

we're now in the bottom of two food chains.
Pretty much we worry, you know.
But we still, in spite of that, the resources didn't flow.
And the active duty military did not necessarily want to have this.
And if they did, they wanted to have it, three-star command, you know, it's close to Washington.
And it was our civilians that said, no, we know the military, it's got to be a four-star.
And we'll actually probably had enough of a lot to do with a powerful flow and a delegation
